subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: BHP (BHP AT) Q4 iron ore output 63mln tons vs. Exp. 62mln tons (Prev. 72mln tons Y/Y), copper output 444k tons vs. Exp. 432k tons (Prev. 463k tons Y/Y)
content:
AUSTRALIA

BHP (BHP AT) - Co. Q4 iron ore output 63mln tons vs. Exp. 62mln tons (Prev. 72mln tons Y/Y), copper output 444k tons vs. Exp. 432k tons (Prev. 463k tons Y/Y), expects to achieve FY unit cost guidance for petroleum, Escondida and Western Australia iron ore. (Newswires)

Chorus (CNU AT) - Co. Q4 total fixed line connections declined by 22k vs. Prev. decline of 14k Q/Q. (Newswires)

Dexus Property (DXS AT) - Co. is said to longer be planning to bid for Telstra’s (TLS AT) property portfolio. (Newswires)

Estia Health (EHE AT) - Co. served class action lawsuit related to disclosure obligations. (Newswires)

Syrah Resources (SYR AT) - Co. reports Q2 graphite output 44k tons vs. guidance of 45k-50k tons. (Newswires)

Vocus (VOC AT) - New Zealand regulator files charges against a unit over customer billing under breach of Fair Trade Act. (Newswires)

Woolworths (WOW AT) - Co. could announce as soon as this week which Big W stores it plans to shut first. (The Australian)

Financials - APRA will receive new powers to crack down on rogue super funds and bankers. (The Australian)

Energy - WTI crude futures fell around 3% to below the USD 58/bbl. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Dentsu (4324 JT) - Co. will acquire majority stake in Ugam Solutions. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Chemical (4010 JT) - Co. is said to have made an investment in Fluence Analytics. (Newswires)

Sapporo Holdings (2501 JT) - Co. is expected oper. loss of around JPY 2bln for H1. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) - Co. is testing hydrogen fluoride etching gas from other sources as export curbs by Japan threaten to cut off the vital chipmaking material to South Korea manufacturers. (Nikkei)

Automakers - South Korea’s auto exports increased by 2.5% Y/Y in H1. (Yonhap)

Geopolitics - US President Trump said US has made tremendous progress with North Korea and that timing is not of the essence, while there were separate reports that North Korea warned planned US-South Korea military drills pose a threat to denuclearisation talks. (Newswires)

Trade - South Korean Finance Minister Hong said they will unveil plans soon to reduce dependence on Japan's industries and urged Japan to withdraw export curbs, while it was also reported that South Korea rejected Japan's arbitration process offer. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said we have a long way to go with China on trade and that the US can put tariffs on another USD 325bln of goods if we want to. (Newswires)

Chinese Premier Li said policy will be fine-tuned in a pre-emptive way at the appropriate time and that downward pressure on China’s economy is increasing, while he reiterated that China will continue to implement prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy, as well as make good use of counter-cyclical measures. (Newswires)

China Foreign Ministry said it is misleading to suggest that China requires a trade deal with the US due to the economy slowing, which was in response to US President Trump’s recent tweet on China's slowing GDP and that many companies want to leave China for non-tariff countries. (Newswires)

New Zealand GDT Dairy Price Change +2.7% (Prev. -0.40%) and Whole Milk Powder Prices +3.6% (Prev. 0.00%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Reports suggested that UK PM candidate Boris Johnson might consider sending MPs home for two weeks in October by scheduling a Queen’s Speech in early November, while the report added that no decision has been made but his campaign confirmed it is one idea under consideration. (Sky)

European Parliament voted in favour of Von Der Leyen as EU Commission President (384 votes for vs. 374 votes needed), while Von Der Leyen later stated she will work constructively with any British PM regarding Brexit negotiations. (Newswires)

  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (May) 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)
  • UK Claimant Count Unemployment Change (Jun) 38.0k vs. Exp. 22.8k (Prev. 23.2k, Rev. 24.5k)
  • UK Average Weekly Earnings 3M (May) Y/Y 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.1%, Rev. 3.2%)
  • German ZEW Current Conditions (Jul) -1.1 vs. Exp. 5.0 (Prev. 7.8)
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Jul) -24.5 vs. Exp. -22.3 (Prev. -21.1)

 

COMMODITIES

API Weekly Energy Inventories (15 July): -1.4mln (exp. -2.7mln, prev. -8.129mln). (Newswires)

US Gulf of Mexico Crude oil production cut by 58% (Prev. 69%) due to Tropical Storm Barry. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump says a lot of progress has been made with Iran and that the US wants to help and work with Iran, while he added that the US is not looking for a regime change and there were separate comments from US Secretary of State Pompeo that Iran has said it is prepared to negotiate about its missile program. However, Iran Head of Media Office later refuted claims that Iran is willing to negotiate on its defensive missile program at some point in which he stated that Iran’s missiles are absolutely and under no condition negotiable with anyone or any country. (Newswires/Twitter)

US President Trump said US has made tremendous progress with North Korea and that timing is not of the essence, while there were separate reports that North Korea warned planned US-South Korea military drills pose a threat to denuclearisation talks. (Newswires)

UK’s Royal Navy is to send a third warship to the Gulf although a defence source stated it is part of a long-standing UK mission and not related to the Iran situation. (The Times)

Yemeni Houthi spokesperson said the group attacked the Saudi city of Khamis Mushait with drones, while the Saudi-led coalition intercepted 2 drones in Yemen's airspace launched by Houthis towards the Saudi city of Jizan. (Al-Arabiya)

US State Department spokesperson said US President Trump is studying all options regarding Turkey sanctions. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed Discount Rate minutes stated nearly all regions supported keeping the discount rate steady aside from St Louis Fed President Bullard who wanted a decrease in the discount rate. (Newswires)

Fed Chair Powell (Neutral) reiterated Fed will act as appropriate to sustain US economic expansion and that uncertainties around solid baseline outlook has increased, while he added overall US growth appears to have moderated in Q2 and that consumer spending growth has bounced back but business investment has slowed. Powell added that the manufacturing sector has been weak since start of 2019 and despite low unemployment and solid growth, inflation pressures remain muted. (Newswires)

Fed's Evans (Voter, Dove) said a little more accommodation may be needed to get inflation back to target and that even if a US-China trade deal is reached, he would still call for cuts unless he saw signs that it would bring up inflation. Furthermore, Evans believes 50bps of easing is required to lift inflation and said it is a question of strategy regarding either a 25bps or 50bps rate cut in July as a larger cut might achieve inflation goals more quickly. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter, Dove) said a rate cut could be warranted based on bond market signals although cuts could be limited or restrained, while Kaplan added it is possible there is more slack in the labour market and that he sees inflation being muted this year. (WSJ)

  • US Industrial Production (Jun) M/M 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.4%). (Newswires)
  • US Manufacturing Output (Jun) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)
  • US Retail Sales (Jun) M/M 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.5%, Rev. 0.4%)
  • US Retail Inventories Ex-Auto (May) 0.3% (Prev. 0.3%)
  • US Business Inventories (May) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.3% (Prev. 0.5%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Goldman Sachs (GS) shares advanced after top and bottom line beats, whilst also increasing quarterly dividend. JP Morgan (JPM) shares rose after the co. reported a beat on top and bottom line and despite a cut in FY19 NII guidance. Wells Fargo (WFC) was under pressure after NIM missed expectations. Finally in the financial sector, Charles Schwab (SCHW) moved higher after the co. reported strong earnings and an increase in active brokerage accounts. Johnson and Johnson (JNJ) shares were under pressure, despite solid earnings, after the drug maker reported a decrease in Worldwide Remicade sales. J. B. Hunt Transport Services (JBHT) shares shot higher after the co. gave robust guidance, bringing other trucking stocks higher. Domino’s Pizza Inc (DPZ) shares sunk after the co. reported disappointing same-stores sales. Energy names sunk with the crude complex after the geopolitical risk premium priced into crude took a hit from US Secretary of State Pompeo comments in which he intimated that Iran may be willing to negotiate about its missile program. Boeing Company (BA) shares were supported by reports that the co. had outlined plans to change the controversial software that was implicated in the crashes, as well as updates to pilot training. Alphabet Inc (GOOG) shares were under pressure after US President Trump said that the government would take a closer look at allegations that the co. had colluded with the Chinese government. Micron (MU) fell after Lynx recommended that clients to take profit on following recent gains. Tesla (TSLA) shares moved lower after the electric automaker opted to drop the cheapest versions of its Model X and S, and adjusted prices across its product range. Abbott Laboratories (ABT) reversed premarket gains, despite news that the co. plans to increase manufacturing capacity for Freestyle Libre, a low-cost continuous glucose monitor, by between three and five times over the next few years. People's United Financial (PBCT) shares fell after the co. announced overnight that it would buy United Financial Bancorp Inc (UBNK) for USD 743mln in a stock deal. Prologis (PLD) shares advanced after the co. announced intentions to buy Black Creek Group's Industrial Property Trust Inc in an all-cash deal valued at about roughly USD 4bln, a move that is set to increase annual core funds from operations (on a per share basis) by between USD 0.05 and USD 0.061. Snap Inc (SNAP) shares fell, despite a PT increase at Evercore ISI. Marathon Oil Corp (MRO) were buoyed by positive comments from JP Morgan, who see an upbeat Q2 based on decent productivity gains. Both Callon Petroleum Co (CPE) and Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) shares rose, a day after the two announced a merger. S&P 500 -0.3% at 3004, NASDAQ-10 -0.5% at 7927, Dow Jones -0.1% at 27335.

The curve bear flattened; yields higher across the curve (2s +3.1bps, 5s +3.5bps, 10s +3.4bps, 30s +3bps) despite dovish rhetoric from Fed officials and geopolitical tensions bubbling away. The complex took its cue from June's retail sales data, which beat expectations. However, the data will likely only have a limited impact on the Fed's policy, where it is expected to cut rates by at least 25bps at its July policy meeting. Pricing for a 50bps rate cut fell slightly in wake of the data, however. And the Fed commentary did little to add to '50bps cut' pricing. The markets have priced 31bps of cuts for the July meeting (implying a 25bps rate cut, with a 24% chance of a 50bps rate cut), and around 66bps of easing is priced through the end of the year (at the end of last week, it was about 70bps). At settlement, major curve spreads were slightly narrower. US T-note futures (U9) settled 8 ticks lower at 126-29+.

US MARKET WRAP 16th July 2019: Dollar boosted after solid retail sales; crude slammed on Pompeo comments
content:
• SNAPSHOT: Equities flat/lower, Treasuries lower, dollar up, crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Pompeo claims Iran ready to negotiate missile program; Iran denies; Solid US retail sales; Trump says US/China deal still a long way off; dovish Fed speak.
  • COMING UP: Data; UK CPI, EU Construction Output, CPI, US Building Permits, Housing Starts, EIA Crude Stocks, Canada CPI, Speakers; ECB’s Coeure, Releases; Fed’s Beige Book, Earnings; Europe; ASML, Ericsson, US; Bank of America, IBM, Abbott Labs, Netflix, eBay, Omnicom. 

* MARKETS WRAP: Stocks came under pressure after US President Trump said that the US and China are still “a long way off” a deal; ranges were thin, however. The dollar rallied back to pre-Powell Semi-Annual Testimony Statement levels on the back of strong retail sales data. Crude dropped on suggestions that Iran was willing to negotiate on its missiles programme, a report that was subsequently denied by Iranian officials. Fed’s Powell reiterated the FOMC’s readiness to act, Kaplan and Evans also reiterated calls for looser policy.

* FED: Nothing particularly new from Fed Chair Powell (Voter), who reiterates the Fed's willingness to act, as he stated at his dual testimonies to lawmakers last week. Interestingly, he did not nod to the strong retail sales data released today, which again reiterates the Fed's dovish stance, and that a July rate cut can be expected. Also interesting was his comments on inflation, which he sees ticking up slightly in the June data (he sees 1.7% Y/Y from 1.6%). Fed’s Evens (Voter) said a little more accommodation may be needed to get inflation back to target; on either a 25bps or 50bps rate cut in July, says it is a question of strategy, a larger cut might achieve inflation goals more quickly. Fed’s Kaplan (Non-Voter) said a rate cut could be warranted based on bond market signals, though said any cuts should be limited or restrained; the comments from the non-voting dove seem to suggest that he is comfortable with the notion of a 25bps rate cut, although 50bps may be a stretch, a sentiment recently expressed by Fed uber-dove (and voter) James Bullard.

* US JUNE RETAIL SALES: US Retail Sales beta expectations at 0.4% M/M in June (Exp. 0.1%); Ex Gas/Autos 0.7% (Prev. 0.5%); Control Group 0.7% (Exp. 0.3%); Ex-Autos 0.4% (Exp. 0.1%). The strong rise in underlying retail sales in June, along with upward revisions to previous months’ gains, suggests that real consumption growth accelerated to 4% annualised in Q2, Capital Economics said. Nevertheless, it would still be a shock if the Fed did not follow through with a 25bps rate cut later at the July meeting, the consultancy write; however, it adds that lingering expectations of a 50bps move look well wide of the mark - a notion that has been given credence by comments from the self-identified, most dovish FOMC participant, James Bullard, who recently said a 50bps insurance rate cut might be excessive.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Secretary of State Pompeo said that Iran is ready to negotiate about its missile programme, in a markedly constructive step forward in terms of diplomacy between Tehran and Washington; However, Iranian officials later denied the report, stating that its missiles were not negotiable; crude clung on to losses, however. President Trump said that a lot of progress has been made with Iran, and that the US wants to provide help and collaboration; Trump added that he does not see a regime change. Elsewhere, Trump said Turkey has ordered more than 100 F-35 planes, but cannot purchase more, as it now has the Russian missile system.

* TRADE: During early morning trade, China’s Foreign Ministry responded to Trump’s criticism of their GDP numbers, stating it is misleading to suggest China requires a US trade deal as the economy is slowing. Later, the WTO appealed that judges rule that the US did not fully comply with a ruling that it should remove certain anti-subsidy tariffs within the Obama-Era disagreement with China, where the WTO appealed the ruling opens up the path for Chinese sanctions on goods in the USA due to WTO rules, unless the disputed tariffs are removed by the US. USTR Lighthizer responded saying the WTO report on the duties ignores objective evidence and findings of the World Bank and OECD and that the US is determined to take all the required steps to ensure an even playing field with China. Mid-session, President Trump stated there is still a long way to go with China in terms of trade and that the US can put tariffs on another additional Chinese goods. Trump also stated that China is supposed to be purchasing US farm products, but he goes onto say ‘We’ll see if they do’.

* US BUSINESS INVENTORIES: Grew 0.3% M/M in May, in line with expectations; the gains were driven by manufacturing (+0.2%), wholesale (+0.4%), and retail (+0.4%) stock building. A modest 0.2% rise in total sales kept the business inventories-to-sales ratio unchanged at 1.39. Oxford Economics notes that following a large 0.6ppt contribution to GDP growth in Q1, inventories are expected to impose a 0.9ppt drag in Q2. Oxford Economics' own real GDP growth tracker stands at 2.0% (annualized), following this morning’s retail sales and inventories data; the Atlanta Fed's gauge rose to 1.6% from 1.4%.

* US INDUSTRIAL/MANUFACTURING PRODUCTION: Industrial production was unchanged in June; industrial production was unchanged in the month of June (analysts had expected a small rise); Manufacturing production rose 0.4% M/M, beating the consensus 0.2%. Wells Fargo's analysts say the headline industrial production was flat as a drop-in utilities output outweighed gains in mining and manufacturing. Despite the second consecutive monthly gain, manufacturing output remains fairly weak.

* GERMAN ZEW: The July print came in at -24, a miss on expectations -22.3 and a decrease from the prior of -21.1. Businesses cited concerns over the US-China trade dispute and Iran tensions as factors for dampened sentiment and said a lasting containment of factors causing uncertainty in export-driven sectors is currently not in sight.

* EUROPE TOP JOBS: Germany's von der Leyen was voted in as European Commission President, by a narrow margin, as expected. Von der Leyen said: The trust you placed in me is confidence you placed in Europe, and confidence in a united and strong Europe, from east to west, from south to north; she added that it was a big responsibility, and that she wants to "work together constructively."

* BREXIT: EU diplomats reportedly are wary of offering any significant new concessions to the UK, but said they have 'ammunition left'. The report said that concessions being mulled in order to avoid a messy no-deal Brexit included technological solutions for the Irish border, a formal link between GBP 39bln 'divorce bill' and any future trade deal, as well as applying the backstop only to Northern Ireland, while a re-drafting of the political declaration is also on the table. Elsewhere, The Times reports a 'hostile' meeting took place between Brexit Secretary Barclay and EU Brexit negotiator Barnier; an unnamed EU official suggested that if the tone of discussions continued in this vein, 'we will be heading for no deal quickly.' In Tuesday trade, Sky reported that Boris Johnson's team is considering a plan to suspend parliament in run up to Brexit; Sky said that Johnson could send MPs home for up to two weeks in October, and insiders reportedly confirmed they are looking at scheduling a Queen's speech to mark the start of a new parliamentary session in early November; Sky explains that Parliament is usually prorogued for between one and two weeks ahead of a Queen's speech, meaning MPs would in effect be unavailable to stop a no-deal Brexit immediately before 31st October.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 8 TICKS LOWER AT 126-29+. The curve bear flattened; yields higher across the curve (2s +3.1bps, 5s +3.5bps, 10s +3.4bps, 30s +3bps) despite dovish rhetoric from Fed officials and geopolitical tensions bubbling away. The complex took its cue from June's retail sales data, which beat expectations. However, the data will likely only have a limited impact on the Fed's policy, where it is expected to cut rates by at least 25bps at its July policy meeting. Pricing for a 50bps rate cut fell slightly in wake of the data, however. And the Fed commentary did little to add to '50bps cut' pricing. The markets have priced 31bps of cuts for the July meeting (implying a 25bps rate cut, with a 24% chance of a 50bps rate cut), and around 66bps of easing is priced through the end of the year (at the end of last week, it was about 70bps). At settlement, major curve spreads were slightly narrower.

* WTI (Q9) SETTLES USD 1.96 LOWER AT USD 57.62; BRENT (U9) SETTLES USD 2.13/BBL LOWER AT USD 64.35: Oil prices were thin-ranged and choppy before a chunky late-session sell off amid a wind-down of US-Iran tensions. Brent futures had a short-lived rally earlier in the session after headlines of the UK Navy sending an additional warship to the Persian Gulf, although closer inspection revealed this was part of a long-term plan established prior to the recent Iran escalation. The two benchmarks tumbled lower in the late session after Washington announced a step forward with Iran, suggesting talks were ready to be held, which saw the market unwind some of the geopolitical risk premium. Looking ahead, the API will release its US energy inventory data after the bell on Tuesday; the Street expects a headline crude draw of 2.7mln. distillates are expected to build by 600k, and gasoline stocks are seen drawing 0.9mln.

* S&P 500 -0.3% at 3004, NASDAQ-10 -0.5% at 7927, Dow Jones  -0.1% at 27335; SECTORS: S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary  -0.2%, S&P 500 Consumer Staples  0%, S&P 500 Energy  -1.1%, S&P 500 Financials  -0.3%, S&P 500 Health Care  -0.5%, S&P 500 Industrials  0.7%, S&P 500 Information Technology  -0.9%, S&P 500 Materials  0.2%, S&P 500 Telecommunication Services  -0.1%, S&P 500 Utilities  -0.6%

* EARNINGS: Goldman Sachs (GS) shares advanced after top and bottom line beats, whilst also increasing quarterly dividend. JP Morgan (JPM) shares rose after the co. reported a beat on top and bottom line and despite a cut in FY19 NII guidance. Wells Fargo (WFC) was under pressure after NIM missed expectations. Finally in the financial sector, Charles Schwab (SCHW) moved higher after the co. reported strong earnings and an increase in active brokerage accounts. Johnson and Johnson (JNJ) shares were under pressure, despite solid earnings, after the drug maker reported a decrease in Worldwide Remicade sales. J. B. Hunt Transport Services (JBHT) shares shot higher after the co. gave robust guidance, bringing other trucking stocks higher. Domino’s Pizza Inc (DPZ) shares sunk after the co. reported disappointing same-stores sales.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Energy names sunk with the crude complex after the geopolitical risk premium priced into crude took a hit from US Secretary of State Pompeo comments in which he intimated that Iran may be willing to negotiate about its missile program. Boeing Company (BA) shares were supported by reports that the co. had outlined plans to change the controversial software that was implicated in the crashes, as well as updates to pilot training. Alphabet Inc (GOOG) shares were under pressure after US President Trump said that the government would take a closer look at allegations that the co. had colluded with the Chinese government. Micron (MU) fell after Lynx recommended that clients to take profit on following recent gains. Tesla (TSLA) shares moved lower after the electric automaker opted to drop the cheapest versions of its Model X and S, and adjusted prices across its product range. Abbott Laboratories (ABT) reversed premarket gains, despite news that the co. plans to increase manufacturing capacity for Freestyle Libre, a low-cost continuous glucose monitor, by between three and five times over the next few years. People's United Financial (PBCT) shares fell after the co. announced overnight that it would buy United Financial Bancorp Inc (UBNK) for USD 743mln in a stock deal. Prologis (PLD) shares advanced after the co. announced intentions to buy Black Creek Group's Industrial Property Trust Inc in an all-cash deal valued at about roughly USD 4bln, a move that is set to increase annual core funds from operations (on a per share basis) by between USD 0.05 and USD 0.061. Snap Inc (SNAP) shares fell, despite a PT increase at Evercore ISI. Marathon Oil Corp (MRO) were buoyed by positive comments from JP Morgan, who see an upbeat Q2 based on decent productivity gains. Both Callon Petroleum Co (CPE) and Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) shares rose, a day after the two announced a merger.

* FX WRAP: USD advanced to pre-Powell testimony levels after a solid retail sales report for June reassured that the consumer sector was in decent shape. GBP sunk to fresh YTD lows of sub 1.24 as no deal Brexit fears resurface; strong UK employment data did little to quell the decline, which saw Cable slip in excess of a dollar on the day. EUR was dragged lower, with dower German ZEW data doing little to help – 1.12 seems to have held. JPY after solid retail sales moved rate differentials in the buck’s favour; Likewise, fellow safe haven asset CHF also weakened. AUD was lower as the RBA minutes kept the door open to further rate cuts; NZD held up relatively better vs the buck, after Q2 CPI was in line. EMFX suffered as a result of dollar strength, with TRY the notable outlier, possibly supported by encouraging jobs and fiscal data and despite continued Turkish determination to continue drilling regardless of possible EU sanctions. MXN was under pressure as President Obrador unveiled plans to rescue state owned oil co. Pemex (ratings agencies have called Pemex a risk to Mexico’s sovereign rating).

* GBP: Sterling saw downside on Tuesday, printing fresh lows just beneath the 1.24 handle. UBS' analysts say the downside was a result of sequencing: There seems to be an inevitability that the EU and UK will arrive at a 'no deal' moment, where both sides go to the edge in their negotiations. The EU wants to get the UK Parliament to blink; the UK Prime Minister needs the EU to compromise. "The problem for investors is, when is the crunch point?" UBS asks, and the bank expects that moment to come at the Oct. 17-18 European Council, but the headlines overnight from Brexit Secretary Barclay's meeting with EU Negotiator Barnier indicates that it might be sooner. Hence today's GBP weakness." The bank this that Parliament will likely stand in the way of 'no deal', making its sales and trading desks a dip buyer of GBP. "However, the moment to do this will only come when both sides enter a 'no deal' standoff. For now, stay short GBP."

* AUD: RBA Minutes released overnight showed the central bank cutting rates (back-to-back) in an effort to "support the necessary growth in employment and incomes, and promote stronger overall economic conditions, which would in turn support a gradual increase in underlying inflation." But the central bank also stated that "a decline in interest rates was unlikely to encourage an unwelcome material pick-up in borrowing by households that would add to medium-term risks in the economy." Looking ahead, the RBA will "monitor developments in the labour market closely and adjust monetary policy if needed," it said. Ahead of the minutes' release, analysts were looking for clues as to whether the RBA's rate cuts were a 'two-and-done' amid the government's latest tax cuts (which is said to be the equivalent of 50bps worth of cuts), or whether it was considering firing more rate cuts. That question, it seems, will be continingent on how the data/trade risks (and by extension the AUD) all evolve, but nevertheless, the possibility of another rate cut before the end of the year remains. Money markets assigned a slightly higher chance of further easing, in wake of the minutes (implied probability rose to 60% from 57%).

* NZD: Q2 CPI printed in line with expectations at +0.6% Q/Q (rebounding from +0.1% Q/Q in Q1) and +1.7% Y/Y. The data was also in line with the RBNZ's May MPS estimate. Core inflation accelerated to 1.7% Y/Y from 1.5%. However, analysts at UBS still look for a 25bps rate cut from the central bank at the August meeting: "It would have taken a material upside surprise to have any influence on our expectation for an August OCR cut – this was not forthcoming," UBS writes. But the bank notes that, "at the margin, and accepting that the immediate outlook for monetary policy is probably going to be more about domestic/global growth and risks thereof, a lift in the RBNZ's preferred measure of underlying inflation would introduce an element of caution about what happens beyond August." Thus, the bank believes that while another cut in November is a risk (and will also depend on the action at other major central banks) it is not its base-case.

* CHF: With the market looking for easing from the ECB next week, watch the CHF, SocGen says. PPI slowed in June sharply, which will once again stoke fears of deflation in Switzerland. "The SNB is sitting on the fence, with a bias to intervene, but it will have to dust off what’s left of its (un)conventional policy tool box if the ECB pulls the trigger on rates and/or QE2 next week or after the summer," SocGen writes. "A 10bps deposit rate cut by the ECB would almost certainly be followed by a cut of the same magnitude in the SNB's 3m Libor midpoint from -0.75% to -0.85% to keep the rate differential constant." SocGen notes that the rise in PPI deflation is dovetailing with CHF appreciation: "All the talk of late has been about dollar intervention, but the closer EURCHF gets to 1.10, the higher the probability that the SNB will act before the US Treasury." With that said, global trade wars and Brexit will make it difficult to completely mitigate support for the CHF between now and October (when the Brexit extension expires), SocGen says.

* BRL: After the Pension Reform vote cleared the Lower House last week, attention is now on the Senate Vote, where 49 of the 81 votes are required. Reports suggest that the government can count on the support of 42, and this shortfall could mean that a vote is pushed back, perhaps until the Congressional recess in August. The key metric to watch is the savings amount (currently estimated at around USD 980bln over a 10-year horizon - if amendments are added that waters down that number, it could pile pressure onto the BRL, some desks warn; a positive outcome, however, could see USDBRL fall to 3.60.

* CNY: UBS recommends keeping an eye on the upcoming Politburo meeting, as well as trade war negotiations, for any change in China's policy direction in H2. The bank says that assuming no further trade war escalation, it expects only modest additional easing and no major new stimulus, and UBS also expects the PBOC to cut RRR by 100 bps, as well as increasing liquidity offering, but not to cut benchmark rates; UBS also expects a modest easing on local government financing.

The complex took its cue from June's retail sales data, which beat expectations. Pricing for a 50bps rate cut fell slightly in wake of the data, however. And the Fed commentary did little to add to '50bps cut' pricing. FX WRAP: USD reigns after solid retail sales data; GBP sees fresh YTD lows as no deal Brexit fears re-emerge
analysis_details:
* FX WRAP: USD advanced to pre-Powell testimony levels after a solid retail sales report for June reassured that the consumer sector was in decent shape. GBP sunk to fresh YTD lows of sub 1.24 as no deal Brexit fears resurface; strong UK employment data did little to quell the decline, which saw Cable slip in excess of a dollar on the day. EUR was dragged lower, with dower German ZEW data doing little to help – 1.12 seems to have held. JPY after solid retail sales moved rate differentials in the buck’s favour; Likewise, fellow safe haven asset CHF also weakened. AUD was lower as the RBA minutes kept the door open to further rate cuts; NZD held up relatively better vs the buck, after Q2 CPI was in line. EMFX suffered as a result of dollar strength, with TRY the notable outlier, possibly supported by encouraging jobs and fiscal data and despite continued Turkish determination to continue drilling regardless of possible EU sanctions. MXN was under pressure as President Obrador unveiled plans to rescue state owned oil co. Pemex (ratings agencies have called Pemex a risk to Mexico’s sovereign rating).

* GBP: Sterling saw downside on Tuesday, printing fresh lows just beneath the 1.24 handle. UBS' analysts say the downside was a result of sequencing: There seems to be an inevitability that the EU and UK will arrive at a 'no deal' moment, where both sides go to the edge in their negotiations. The EU wants to get the UK Parliament to blink; the UK Prime Minister needs the EU to compromise. "The problem for investors is, when is the crunch point?" UBS asks, and the bank expects that moment to come at the Oct. 17-18 European Council, but the headlines overnight from Brexit Secretary Barclay's meeting with EU Negotiator Barnier indicates that it might be sooner. Hence today's GBP weakness." The bank this that Parliament will likely stand in the way of 'no deal', making its sales and trading desks a dip buyer of GBP. "However, the moment to do this will only come when both sides enter a 'no deal' standoff. For now, stay short GBP."

* AUD: RBA Minutes released overnight showed the central bank cutting rates (back-to-back) in an effort to "support the necessary growth in employment and incomes, and promote stronger overall economic conditions, which would in turn support a gradual increase in underlying inflation." But the central bank also stated that "a decline in interest rates was unlikely to encourage an unwelcome material pick-up in borrowing by households that would add to medium-term risks in the economy." Looking ahead, the RBA will "monitor developments in the labour market closely and adjust monetary policy if needed," it said. Ahead of the minutes' release, analysts were looking for clues as to whether the RBA's rate cuts were a 'two-and-done' amid the government's latest tax cuts (which is said to be the equivalent of 50bps worth of cuts), or whether it was considering firing more rate cuts. That question, it seems, will be continingent on how the data/trade risks (and by extension the AUD) all evolve, but nevertheless, the possibility of another rate cut before the end of the year remains. Money markets assigned a slightly higher chance of further easing, in wake of the minutes (implied probability rose to 60% from 57%).

* NZD: Q2 CPI printed in line with expectations at +0.6% Q/Q (rebounding from +0.1% Q/Q in Q1) and +1.7% Y/Y. The data was also in line with the RBNZ's May MPS estimate. Core inflation accelerated to 1.7% Y/Y from 1.5%. However, analysts at UBS still look for a 25bps rate cut from the central bank at the August meeting: "It would have taken a material upside surprise to have any influence on our expectation for an August OCR cut – this was not forthcoming," UBS writes. But the bank notes that, "at the margin, and accepting that the immediate outlook for monetary policy is probably going to be more about domestic/global growth and risks thereof, a lift in the RBNZ's preferred measure of underlying inflation would introduce an element of caution about what happens beyond August." Thus, the bank believes that while another cut in November is a risk (and will also depend on the action at other major central banks) it is not its base-case.

* CHF: With the market looking for easing from the ECB next week, watch the CHF, SocGen says. PPI slowed in June sharply, which will once again stoke fears of deflation in Switzerland. "The SNB is sitting on the fence, with a bias to intervene, but it will have to dust off what’s left of its (un)conventional policy tool box if the ECB pulls the trigger on rates and/or QE2 next week or after the summer," SocGen writes. "A 10bps deposit rate cut by the ECB would almost certainly be followed by a cut of the same magnitude in the SNB's 3m Libor midpoint from -0.75% to -0.85% to keep the rate differential constant." SocGen notes that the rise in PPI deflation is dovetailing with CHF appreciation: "All the talk of late has been about dollar intervention, but the closer EURCHF gets to 1.10, the higher the probability that the SNB will act before the US Treasury." With that said, global trade wars and Brexit will make it difficult to completely mitigate support for the CHF between now and October (when the Brexit extension expires), SocGen says.

* BRL: After the Pension Reform vote cleared the Lower House last week, attention is now on the Senate Vote, where 49 of the 81 votes are required. Reports suggest that the government can count on the support of 42, and this shortfall could mean that a vote is pushed back, perhaps until the Congressional recess in August. The key metric to watch is the savings amount (currently estimated at around USD 980bln over a 10-year horizon - if amendments are added that waters down that number, it could pile pressure onto the BRL, some desks warn; a positive outcome, however, could see USDBRL fall to 3.60.

* CNY: UBS recommends keeping an eye on the upcoming Politburo meeting, as well as trade war negotiations, for any change in China's policy direction in H2. The bank says that assuming no further trade war escalation, it expects only modest additional easing and no major new stimulus, and UBS also expects the PBOC to cut RRR by 100 bps, as well as increasing liquidity offering, but not to cut benchmark rates; UBS also expects a modest easing on local government financing.

subject: Iran Head of Media Office appears to cast doubts on Pompeo assertion that Iran's missiles are negotiable
content:
• In a series of tweets, he said:
  • "We categorically reject the AP’s characterization of [Iran Foreign Minister Zarif] comments to NBC News that "if the US wants to talk about missiles, it should stop selling weapons, including missiles, to regional states” as meaning that Iran is willing to negotiate on its defensive missile program at some point. Iran’s missiles and its missiles are absolutely and under no condition negotiable with anyone or any country, period. Surely AP reporters are familiar enough with conversational English to know and understand and are able to contextualize comments on the hypothetical, as well as parrying with words to make a point. Drawing a false conclusion in pursuit of headlines, when what was said in the context was obvious, only leads to a diminution of the standing of the press with the public."
  • Via Iran's spokesperson on Twitter
analysis_details: NOTE: Earlier, US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran has said it is prepared to negotiate about its missile program, although the spokesperson appears to cast doubt on that suggestion. Crude dropped in wake of Pompeo's comments, and are yet to recover, (WTI fell from USD 59.40 to USD 57.20 in wake of Pompeo's comments, last trades at 57.94)

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY back in control, as Cable careers towards 1.2400 and Eur/Usd eyes 1.1200
content:
USD/CAD

US Dollar bulls are back in the driving seat after significantly stringer than expected US retail sales data, and a particularly buoyant control group that extended a run of positive prints to 4 months in June. The beats vs consensus more than overshadowed a slender ip miss to boost the Greenback almost across the board, but with the Loonie holding up better than the rest in major terms after Canadian securities tallies for may (albeit belatedly). Usd/Cad is still straddling 1.3050 even though the DXY has cemented gains above the psychological 97.000 to a 97.342 peak and is back within striking distance of 97.500 ahead of chart resistance at 97.588 (last Tuesday’s high).

GBP/EUR

Already the clear G10 underperformer, the Pound lost more ground as a series of technical levels and symbolic or sentimental numbers gave way, like 1.2500 and 1.2450 vs the Buck and 0.9000 then 0.9025 against the Euro. The catalyst remains the same for Sterling sellers, ongoing UK political uncertainty and knock-on implications for Brexit as the clock ticks down to October 31. On that note, reports circulated that front-runner to replace outgoing UK PM May could schedule the Queen’s Speech form early November and effectively send MPs home for 2 weeks in October. Hence, not even blow-out wages came to Gbp’s rescue for more than a brief period as Cable proceeded to retest flash crash lows circa 1.2409 ahead of purported option barriers at 1.2400, and Eur/Gbp reached 0.9040+ before paring back.

CHF/JPY 

The renowned safe-havens have both lost ground in wake of the aforementioned upbeat US consumption numbers, which nudged July FOMC easing expectations further towards 25 bp from 50 bp, like headline NFP. The Franc slipped from around 0.9837 at best towards 0.9890 and Yen to roughly 108.25 compared to 107.83 or so as UST/JGB yields diverged.

AUD/NZD

The Antipodean Dollars look set to end Tuesday’s EU session on a more even keel as Aud/Usd sits a bit more comfortably above 0.7000 within a 0.7044-24 range vs Nzd/Usd in danger of losing grip of 0.6700 between 0.6737-09 parameters. The Kiwi did not get any support or impetus from deent rebounds in GDT auction prices and having failed to build on post-NZ Q2 inflation momentum overnight may turn technically weaker if it fails to reclaim the 200 DMA at 0.6718 and/or retreats through 1.0500 on the cross.

EM

Encouraging Turkish jobs and fiscal data may have helped Usd/Try buck the broad trend as the Foreign Ministry vowed to continue drilling regardless of EU sanctions, but Usd/Mxn rebounded to 19.0700 from 18.9560 even though some details of aid for PEMEX were unveiled. Note, the Lira actually peered above 5.7000 within a moderately firmer range vs the Dollar down to 5.7230.

Talking Crude: Prices finding support ahead of inventories
analysis_details:
Energy markets are trading a touch firmer ahead of this evening’s API energy inventory data. Crude had been drifting lower with gratitude to the gradual de-escalation of weather concerns in the Gulf of Mexico, additionally, the EIA on Monday said it expects US shale output to rise to a record 8.55mln BPD (it upped its view by 49k BPD) is offering some dampening effect. Worth highlighting that RBOB gasoline, which has been known to lead price movement in energy markets, has been trading lower and breaking through technical levels, which PVM analysts suggest, “It is not advised to be long. Be prepared for weakness.”

Looking into the EIA drilling report, although it forecasts the 49k BPD rise in production for August in the Shale region, this is yet another month of a declining rate of growth in tight oil plays. The August 2018 forecast by the EIA had production rising by 143k BPD, and the March 2019 forecast was 84k, the general trend has been moving lower. Production has been saturating in the US after a long run of cash abundant Shale producers draining oil reservoirs and eventually yielding less as drilling locations become less far-and-wide apart. This has been part of the rationale for consolidation in the US E&P sector as the smaller inefficient producers face an exodus, where Callon Petroleum (CPE) acquiring Carrizo (CRZO) in an all-stock deal is the latest shake-up. The deal expresses the desperation in the sector, Carrizo has agreed to the transaction with its share price near record lows. The deal rings alarm bells as - until recently - E&P players in the Shale region usually banked on waiting for the next activity pickup in the sector. Carrizo clearly isn’t confident this time around.

  • Goldman Sachs Group (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) (USD) report Q2 EPS 5.81 (exp. 4.92), revenue 9.46bln (exp. 8.9bln), boosts dividend to 1.25/shr (prev. 0.85), Net Interest Income 1.071bln (Exp. 1.132bln, Prev. 1.465bln). FICC was an underperforming unit, whilst Equities was promising.
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) (USD) report Q2 adj. EPS 2.58 (exp. 2.46), revenue 20.6bln (exp. 20.29bln), maintains FY19 EPS view 8.53-8.63 (exp. 8.60), raises FY19 revenue view 82.4bln-83.2bln (exp. 81.22bln). Worldwide Remicade Sales 1.1bln (prev. 1.3bln YY).
  • JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) (USD) report Q2 EPS 2.82 (exp. 2.50), revenue 28.8bln (exp. 28.9bln). Cut FY19 NII view to USD 57.5bln (prev. USD 58bln), citing expectations of three Fed rate cuts in 2019. NII 14.5bln (up 7%), "driven by balance sheet growth and mix, as well as the impact of higher rates". Equity Sales & Trading revenue USD 1.73bln (exp. USD 1.82bln), Investment Banking revenue USD 1.78bln (exp. USD 1.81bln).
  • Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) (Information Technology/Systems Software) has had its PT raised to USD 153 from USD 147 and its Outperform rating maintained at BMO Capital; analyst Keith Bachman commented that the tech giant should "easily meet or modestly exceed" consensus expectations in its upcoming earnings release. Bachman said that the co. is able to serve as both a defensive and offensive stock, before adding that the new PT reflects his conviction that the co. will be able to sustain a double-digit revenue growth rate.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet Inc (GOOG) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - US President Trump says the government will take a closer look into Google, in regard to allegations of collusion with the Chinese government.
  • Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) (USD) employees in the US, UK, Germany, Spain and Poland went on strike on Prime Day on Monday, Business Insider reported. Reportedly, Unions have criticised the extension of Prime Day to two days, which, when combined with the promise of one-day delivery, will push workers to their physical limits as if they are "trained triathletes", Unions added. Elsewhere, the co. has a new promotion for Prime Day shoppers; customers will be able to earn USD 10 worth of credit if they allow Amazon to track the websites they visit, with the company planning to use this data to improve its general marketing, products and services.
  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals), Amazon.com Inc. (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail), Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) and Alphabet Inc (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) executives will face the House Judiciary Committee's antitrust panel to discuss competition in online markets; the committee is likely to quiz the companies on ongoing antitrust probes into each company at the DoJ and FTC, as well as allegations that they seek to thwart smaller competitors.
  • Micron Technology (MU) (Information Technology/Semiconductors) – Lynx has reportedly recommended clients to take profit on Micron shares following recent gains. Lynx analysts believe the co.’s core memory business is “skating on thin ice” and think it likely that stock price may revisit USD 30.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) has reportedly dropped the cheapest versions of its Model X and S and will adjust prices across its product range; including the starting price of its Model X and Model S, which are going up to USD 84,990 and USD 79,990 respectively. In separate news, some employees say they were pressured to take shortcuts to hit production targets, which included reducing testing for water leaks and using electrical tape to make quick fixes during Model 3 assembly, reported CNBC.

S&P 500

  • Abbott Laboratories (ABT) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) is reportedly planning to increase manufacturing capacity for Freestyle Libre, a low-cost continuous glucose monitor, by between three and five times over the next few years, as the co. aims to reach more patients worldwide. Reportedly, the boost in production will occur in H2 19, as the co. gears up for a Freestyle Libra 2 launch in the US (which is currently under regulatory review).
  • CBS Corp. (CBS) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) and Viacom Inc. (VIAB) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) may set the date for their merger pact for August 8th, CNBC reported, as on that day, both companies report Q2 earnings, although the announcement could come sooner or later the report caveats.
  • Charles Schwab Corp (SCHW) (Financials/Capital Markets) Q2 19 (USD): EPS 0.66 (exp. 0.65), Revenue 2.68bln (exp. 2.67bln). Active brokerage accounts of 11.97mln vs. Prev. 11.20mln [end of Q2].
  • J. B. Hunt Transport Services (JBHT) (Industrials/Trucking) (USD) report Q2 EPS 1.23 (exp. 1.35), revenue 2.26bln (exp. 2.26bln), operating income 0.1931bln (down 10% Y/Y), Intermodal revenue 1.15bln (down 1% Y/Y), Intermodal operating income 0.1244bln (down 7% Y/Y), intermodal load volumes down 8%.
  • People's United Financial (PBCT) (Financials/Thrifts & Mortgage Finance) announced overnight that it would buy United Financial Bancorp Inc (UBNK) (Financials/Thrifts & Mortgage Finance) for roughly USD 743mln in a stock deal. United Financial shareholders will receive 0.875 shares of People's United stock for each share they hold, valuing the company at USD 14.53 on a per-share basis (based on Monday's close price). People's United expects to add USD 0.07 to its EPS and the deal is expected to close in Q4.
  • Prologis (PLD) (Real Estate/Industrial REITs) announced on Monday intentions to buy Black Creek Group's Industrial Property Trust Inc in an all-cash deal valued at about roughly USD 4bln. The co. expects the deal to add between USD 0.05 and USD 0.061 to its annual core funds from operations (on a per share basis), with the deal expected to close late 2019/early 2020.
  • Twitter, Inc. (TWTR) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) (USD) has decided that US President Trump's recent tweets attacking four minority democratic congresswomen did not violate its policies, despite earlier indicating that any violating tweets will be flagged and downranked, reported Gizmodo. This decision comes amid continued criticism the social media platform has faced from the President, where he has accused the co. of anti-conservative bias.
  • Wells Fargo & Co (WFC) (Financials/Banks) Q2 19 (USD): adj. EPS 1.30 (exp. 1.15), Revenue 21.6bln (exp. 20.93bln). NIM 2.82% (exp. 2.85%, prev. 2.91%); NII 12.1bln (exp. 12.2bln). Guides FY19 expenses between USD 52-53bln and non-interest expenses towards the higher end of the range.

OTHER

  • Alibaba (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) has reportedly developed a cardiovascular recognition technology which can help to detect heart disease, Nikkei reported.
  • Energy Transfer (ET) (Energy/Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) is reportedly considering the sale of a 33% stake in the Rover pipeline.
  • Snap Inc (SNAP) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) had its PT raised to USD 16 from USD 12 at Evercore ISI, who cited an improvement in Snap's downloads following the release of a popular gender-swap filter in mid-May, and as user trends have stabilized.
  • Vale (VALE) (Materials/Metals & Mining) will pay roughly USD 105.5mln in compensation to workers impacted by the January dam disaster, which killed over 200 people.

content:
•   USD rises broadly v. G10 ahead of key ret. sales, ind. prod, NAHB & Fedspeak.
  •   CAD consolidating just below Friday’s high; risk of near-term consolidation.
  •   EUR softens on ZEW disappointment; options market increasingly favourable.

  •   JPY extends Monday’s tight consolidation; upside risk on sentiment/positioning.

subject: Chinese Premier Li says  policy will be fine-tuned in a preemptive way at appropriate time, downward pressure on Chinese economy is increasing, reiterates that China will continue to implement prudent monetary policy and proactive fiscal policy
content: • Will make good use of counter-cyclical measures
analysis_details:
• Desk notes the language used by Premier Li, i.e "preemptive, counter-cyclical", seems like he is trying to convey an insurance move (with the Fed expected to ease this meeting)
  • Note: Earlier UBS recommended keeping an eye on the upcoming Politburo meeting, as well as trade war negotiations, for any change in China's policy direction in H2. The bank says that assuming no further trade war escalation, it expects only modest additional easing and no major new stimulus, and UBS also expects the PBOC to cut RRR by 100 bps, as well as increasing liquidity offering, but not to cut benchmark rates; UBS also expects a modest easing on local government financing.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are largely flat [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%] as US earnings season gets underway
  • China’s Foreign Ministry says it is misleading to suggest China requires a US trade deal as the economy is slowing
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US Import/Export Prices, Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Manufacturing Output & Business Inventories, EC President Voting, Fed Discount Rate Minutes
  • Speakers: Fed’s Powell, Evans, Bowman, Bostic & Kaplan, BoE’s Carney
  • Earnings: JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo, J&J, Kinder Morgan & Charles Schwab

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region indecisive following modest gains on Wall St where all major indices notched fresh record highs before pulling back on cautiousness heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (Unch.) was choppy as weakness across energy and financials offset the upside in mining names including Rio Tinto, in which record high iron ore prices in China helped shares in the industry giant shrug off a decline in Q2 production and shipments. Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) underperformed on return from the extended weekend as it reacted to the recent downside in USD/JPY, while Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were lacklustre as markets digested a slew of corporate earnings and guidance announcements but with downside also stemmed after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations following a 3-week hiatus. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher following the recent upside in T-notes and amid the cautious overnight risk sentiment, while the BoJ were also present in the market for 5yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 160bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8710 (Prev. 6.8677)

South Korean Foreign Ministry official said US indicated it is willing to play a suitable role in trying to ease Japan and South Korea tensions, while it was later reported that South Korea, Japan and US officials will meet in Washington DC on July 26th. (Newswires)

US

China Foreign Ministry say it is misleading to suggest that China requires a trade deal with the US due to the economy slowing, in response to US President Trump tweeting on China's slowing GDP, saying many companies want to leave China for non-tariff countries. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Last week’s meeting of chief Brexit negotiators was said to be one of the most difficult according to EU officials that anticipate discussions could turn more hostile under the next British government, while reports added the EU is mulling potential concessions it could offer to avoid a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) says the ECB must not be market dependent, this also includes relying too much on inflation expectations on market based measures, at the next ECB meeting (24th-25th July), policymakers will asses real economic data and will act appropriately when required. (Newswires)

UK Avg Wk Earnings 3M YY May 3.4% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.1%, Rev. 3.2%)

- UK Avg Earnings (Ex-Bonus) May 3.6% vs. Exp. 3.5% (Prev. 3.4%)

- UK Claimant Count Unem Chng Jun 38.0k vs. Exp. 22.8k (Prev. 23.2k, Rev. 24.5k)

- UK ILO Unemployment Rate May 3.8% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment Jul -24.5 vs. Exp. -22.3 (Prev. -21.1)

- German ZEW Current Conditions Jul -1.1 vs. Exp. 5.0 (Prev. 7.8)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea released full text of its new constitution in which it affirmed that North Korea is a nuclear state, according to South Korea press reports. (Newswires)

EU Council said it suspended high-level dialogue with Turkey for the time-being due to the country’s continued illegal drilling activities in Cypriot territorial waters. (Newswires)

- Subsequently, Turkish Foreign Ministry says there is no need to take EU steps on Turkey too seriously. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major indices are relatively flat [Eurostoxx 50 +0.1%] following on from a mixed Asia-Pac handover and heading into key US data, earning seasons and a slew of Central Bank speakers. Sectors are mixed with some mild underperformance seen in energy names following yesterday’s decline in the complex. In terms of individual movers, Burberry (+12.0%) dominates the Stoxx 600 after sales growth topped estimates in Q1, whilst earnings also supported Yara (+3.6%) shares. On the flip side, Telenor (-5.4%) plumbed the depths despite an upgrade at DNB Markets as the Co’s Q2 adj. EBITDA fell short of expectations. Elsewhere, Daimler (-1.0%) and Fiat Chrysler (-3.6%) shares moved accordingly to initiations at Goldman Sachs. Other notable movers include Bayer (+1.5%) which received some reprieve after a US reduced damages award against Co. in Roundup case to USD 25.3mln vs. Prev. USD 80mln, and added that the original punitive damages award was too high. Finally, AMS (-1.0%) shares slipped, albeit they have since recovered off of lows, after the Co. called off takeover talks with Osram Licht (+0.1%) as it did not see “sufficient basis” to continue discussions. As a reminder, today will see the release of earnings from three DJIA companies; Johnson & Johnson (3.34% weighting), JP Morgan (2.82% weighting) and Goldman Sachs (5.24% weighting), for a full schedule please visit the Daily US Earnings Estimates on the Research Suite.

FX

GBP/EUR - Sterling continues to slide amidst the ongoing race to become new Tory leader/PM and pick-up the Brexit baton, with little support coming from firmer than expected AHE metrics that could feed into inflation and underpin consumption. Indeed, Cable only managed a fleeting and feeble bounce in wake of the UK data before resuming its decline through 1.2500 towards 1.2450 and the recent low where stops are said to be waiting before more at 1.2425. Moreover, Eur/Gbp is firmly back above 0.9000 and testing half year peaks of 0.9025 even though the single currently is soft vs a broadly perky Dollar (DXY back over 97.000) and extending below 1.1250 and several DMAs, like the 100 and 50 markers at 1.1253 and 1.1243 respectively. Note, decent, but not quite 1 bn option expiry interest at 1.1250 may yet cushion Eur/Usd into the NY cut after a rather downbeat German ZEW survey.

NZD/AUD - Conversely, the Kiwi remains underpinned on the 0.6700 handle vs its US counterpart, just above the 200 DMA (0.6718) and close to 1.0450 against the Aussie following in line NZ CPI prints for Q2 overnight, while Aud/Usd has pulled up ahead of 0.7050 on the back of RBA minutes underlining data (jobs primarily) dependency in terms of future policy moves after 50 bp worth of easing in June and July.

CHF/JPY/CAD - The Franc, Yen and Loonie are all still narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with Usd/Chf, Usd/Jpy and Usd/Cad pivoting 0.9850, 108.00 and 1.3050 respectively and eyeing US data for more direction (retail sales and ip) in the absence of anything scheduled independently, or a raft of Fed speakers ahead of the pre-July FOMC blackout period.

EM - The Lira remains relatively resistant in the face of EU sanctions and Turkish macro developments may be providing a buffer as quarterly unemployment fell markedly and the budget balance revealed a slightly narrower shortfall. Usd/Try is hovering close to the base of a 5.7230-7040 range.

RBA minutes from July 2nd meeting stated that the board will adjust policy if needed to support growth and that the board will observe the labour market closely, with an improvement needed to spur growth. Minutes noted that spare capacity will likely stay in the labour market for some time and lower interest rates will keep AUD weaker than would otherwise be the case, while it added that risks from trade disputes remained high and that inflation is subdued in developed countries. (Newswires)

New Zealand CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.5%)

FX Option Expiries:

- EUR/USD: 1.1180-95 (1.8BLN), 1.1215 (380M), 1.1235-45 (600M), 1.1250 (888M), 1.1310 (588M), 1.1380-1.1400 (1BLN)

- GBP/USD: 1.2500 (515M), 1.2605-15 (433M)

FIXED INCOME 

It remains too early to tell, but the signs are encouraging for Bunds and Gilts in terms of maintaining their recovery mojo from the depths of recent lows. Indeed, after opening and/or early wobbles the 10 year benchmarks have both extended rebounds through upside technical hurdles on the way to intraday highs of 172.68 and 131.07 respectively (+35 and +23 ticks on the day). UK debt is lagging somewhat in wake of frothy wage metrics and long end issuance, while German/Eurozone bonds have no doubt taken on board another pretty bleak survey via ZEW. However, US Treasuries have not really piggy-backed gains ahead of some key data and lots of Fed speak, plus earnings and API.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are little changed thus far amid the tentative tone ahead of the aforementioned risk events. Albeit, the energy complex has held on to most of yesterday’s losses with the former resting just below the 60/bbl mark whilst the latter hovers south of 67/bbl. Over in the Gulf, crude producers and refiners have started restoring operations after the passing of storm Barry, albeit 69% of output still remains locked, down from the 73% output curb on Sunday. Elsewhere, gold remains within a tight range ahead of key US data. Meanwhile, China iron ore futures surged as much as 4.6% to a record high on upbeat demand prospects and in a follow-through of the China industrial output beat. Subsequently, China's Dalian Commodity Exchange says transaction fees for iron ore futures will be adjusted as of July 18.

NHC have most recently stated that Barry has turned into a post-tropical cyclone and that flash flooding is still likely. (Newswires)

Crude loading at Iraq's Basra oil export terminal resume following a fire, according to officials. (Newswires)

Indonesian oil lifting is seen at 754k BPD, according to the Finance Ministry. (Newswires)

China Refined copper output (June) 804k Tonnes, +11.8%., China Statistics Bureau. (Newswires)

Indeed, Cable only managed a fleeting and feeble bounce in wake of the UK data before resuming its decline through 1.2500 towards 1.2450 and the recent low where stops are said to be waiting before more at 1.2425. Moreover, Eur/Gbp is firmly back above 0.9000 and testing half year peaks of 0.9025 even though the single currently is soft vs a broadly perky Dollar (DXY back over 97.000) and extending below 1.1250 and several DMAs, like the 100 and 50 markers at 1.1253 and 1.1243 respectively. Note, decent, but not quite 1 bn option expiry interest at 1.1250 may yet cushion Eur/Usd into the NY cut after a rather downbeat German ZEW survey.

NZD/AUD - Conversely, the Kiwi remains underpinned on the 0.6700 handle vs its US counterpart, just above the 200 DMA (0.6718) and close to 1.0450 against the Aussie following in line NZ CPI prints for Q2 overnight, while Aud/Usd has pulled up ahead of 0.7050 on the back of RBA minutes underlining data (jobs primarily) dependency in terms of future policy moves after 50 bp worth of easing in June and July.

CHF/JPY/CAD - The Franc, Yen and Loonie are all still narrowly mixed vs the Greenback, with Usd/Chf, Usd/Jpy and Usd/Cad pivoting 0.9850, 108.00 and 1.3050 respectively and eyeing US data for more direction (retail sales and ip) in the absence of anything scheduled independently, or a raft of Fed speakers ahead of the pre-July FOMC blackout period.

EM - The Lira remains relatively resistant in the face of EU sanctions and Turkish macro developments may be providing a buffer as quarterly unemployment fell markedly and the budget balance revealed a slightly narrower shortfall. Usd/Try is hovering close to the base of a 5.7230-7040 range.

FIXED INCOME

It remains too early to tell, but the signs are encouraging for Bunds and Gilts in terms of maintaining their recovery mojo from the depths of recent lows. Indeed, after opening and/or early wobbles the 10 year benchmarks have both extended rebounds through upside technical hurdles on the way to intraday highs of 172.68 and 131.07 respectively (+35 and +23 ticks on the day). UK debt is lagging somewhat in wake of frothy wage metrics and long end issuance, while German/Eurozone bonds have no doubt taken on board another pretty bleak survey via ZEW. However, US Treasuries have not really piggy-backed gains ahead of some key data and lots of Fed speak, plus earnings and API.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are little changed thus far amid the tentative tone ahead of the aforementioned risk events. Albeit, the energy complex has held on to most of yesterday’s losses with the former resting just below the 60/bbl mark whilst the latter hovers south of 67/bbl. Over in the Gulf, crude producers and refiners have started restoring operations after the passing of storm Barry, albeit 69% of output still remains locked, down from the 73% output curb on Sunday. Elsewhere, gold remains within a tight range ahead of key US data. Meanwhile, China iron ore futures surged as much as 4.6% to a record high on upbeat demand prospects and in a follow-through of the China industrial output beat. Subsequently, China's Dalian Commodity Exchange says transaction fees for iron ore futures will be adjusted as of July 18.

content:

16th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region indecisive following the modest finish on Wall St where all major indices notched fresh record highs before pulling back on cautiousness heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (Unch.) was choppy as weakness across energy and financials offset the upside in mining names including Rio Tinto, in which record high iron ore prices in China helped shares in the industry giant shrug off a decline in Q2 production and shipments. Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) underperformed on return from the extended weekend as it reacted to the recent downside in USD/JPY, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were lacklustre as markets digested a slew of corporate earnings and guidance announcements but with downside also stemmed after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations following a 3-week hiatus. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher following the recent upside in T-notes and amid the cautious overnight risk sentiment, while the BoJ were also present in the market for 5yr-10yr JGBs.

FTSE 100

Q2 aluminium output 803k tons vs. Prev. 858k tons Y/Y, while it announces completion of sale in Rossing uranium mine and raises CAPEX for Oyu Tolgoi project to between USD 6.5bln-7.2bln from USD 5.3bln. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mixed with the region indecisive following modest gains on Wall St
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has stated that he and USTR Lighthizer could visit China for further talks if progress is made
  • EU is reportedly mulling potential concessions it could offer to avoid a no-deal Brexit
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Jobs, German ZEW US Import/Export Prices, Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Manufacturing Output & Business Inventories, EC President Voting, Fed Discount Rate Minutes and supply from the UK
  • Speakers: Fed’s Powell, Evans, Bowman, Bostic & Kaplan, BoE’s Carney & ECB’s de Galhau
  • Earnings: JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Wells Fargo, J&J, Kinder Morgan & Charles Schwab

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region indecisive following modest gains on Wall St where all major indices notched fresh record highs before pulling back on cautiousness heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (Unch.) was choppy as weakness across energy and financials offset the upside in mining names including Rio Tinto, in which record high iron ore prices in China helped shares in the industry giant shrug off a decline in Q2 production and shipments. Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) underperformed on return from the extended weekend as it reacted to the recent downside in USD/JPY, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were lacklustre as markets digested a slew of corporate earnings and guidance announcements but with downside also stemmed after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations following a 3-week hiatus. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally higher following the recent upside in T-notes and amid the cautious overnight risk sentiment, while the BoJ were also present in the market for 5yr-10yr JGBs.

PBoC injected CNY 160bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8710 (Prev. 6.8677)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he expects to have another call with his Chinese counterpart on trade this week and that there is a "good chance" he and USTR Lighthizer could visit China for further talks if progress is made. (Newswires)

South Korean Foreign Ministry official said US indicated it is willing to play a suitable role in trying to ease Japan and South Korea tensions, while it was later reported that South Korea, Japan and US officials will meet in Washington DC on July 26th. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Last week’s meeting of chief Brexit negotiators was said to be one of the most difficult according to EU officials that anticipate discussions could turn more hostile under the next British government, while reports added the EU is mulling potential concessions it could offer to avoid a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY remained firm and eyed a retest of the 97.00 level to the upside after the prior day’s gains, partially spurred by better than expected NY Fed Manufacturing data. As such, EUR/USD languished near 1.1250 where there is a notable option expiry for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD was stuck at the prior day’s lows and within close proximity to the 1.2500 level. Of note for GBP, the Brexit negotiators’ meeting last week was said to be one of the most difficult with officials poising themselves for more hostile talks under the next UK government, and a recent note from Deutsche Bank suggested the probability of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit is at 45%. USD/JPY was range-bound after having failed to sustain an early reclaim of the 108.00 handle and antipodeans were also relatively uneventful with only a muted reaction seen in AUD/USD from the RBA minutes which stated the board will adjust policy if needed to support growth and suggested the central bank will likely be data dependent, while NZD/USD gradually benefitted after Q2 CPI data printed inline with expectations.

RBA minutes from July 2nd meeting stated that the board will adjust policy if needed to support growth and that the board will observe the labour market closely, with an improvement needed to spur growth. Minutes noted that spare capacity will likely stay in the labour market for some time and lower interest rates will keep AUD weaker than would otherwise be the case, while it added that risks from trade disputes remained high and that inflation is subdued in developed countries. (Newswires)

New Zealand CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires) New Zealand CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.5%) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were flat amid a tentative risk tone which provided respite for WTI crude futures from yesterday’s pressures amid reports producers were returning workforce personnel to platforms after Barry proved to be less damaging than anticipated, and with the selling exacerbated as stops were tripped through USD 60.00. Nonetheless, price action has since quietened overnight with participants looking ahead to the latest inventory reports beginning with the APIs later, while NHC also announced that Barry has turned into a post-tropical cyclone. Elsewhere, gold was flat with the precious metal restricted by a sturdy greenback and copper also proceeded sideways due to the cautious risk tone which saw prices fail to take impetus from the fresh record highs in Chinese iron prices.

US Gulf of Mexico crude oil production cut by 69% (Prev. 73%) due to tropical storm Barry, while the NHC later stated that Barry has turned into a post-tropical cyclone and that flash flooding is still likely. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

North Korea released full text of its new constitution in which it affirmed that North Korea is a nuclear state, according to South Korea press reports. (Newswires)

 

UN said that all Yemeni warring sides have agreed on a mechanism and new measure to reinforce a ceasefire and de-escalation, which will be put in place as soon as possible. (Newswires)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif said sanctions relief must precede talks. In related news, EU's Foreign Policy Chief Mogherini stated that none of the signatories of the Iran deal have signalled an intention to invoke a dispute mechanism for the time being and that none of the parties believe Iran's breaches are significant non-compliance, while she added the Iran deal is not in good health but is still alive although she cannot say if it is in its last hours. (Newswires)

EU Council said it suspended high-level dialogue with Turkey for the time-being due to the country’s continued illegal drilling activities in Cypriot territorial waters. (Newswires)

US

The T-plex saw some downward pressure following mixed Chinese data overnight however losses were pared back throughout the rest of the session, volume on Monday was weak ahead of key data points such as US retail sales on Tuesday and a slew of fed speak later in the week as we head towards the blackout period. Analysts noted some large block buys providing momentum, with 8.3k in TUU9 at 107.113 and 14.4k in TYU9 at 127’01. At settlement the curve had flattened, with the 30-year yield down by c. 2.5bps, and the 2s/30s contracted by just over 2bps. US T-note futures (U9) settled 2 ticks higher at 127-05+.

US President Trump said if the USMCA deal does not pass congress he has a better plan, while there were comments from White House Adviser Navarro that President Trump will sign an order which looks to increase the domestic content threshold for domestic made iron and steel. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said he urged congress to raise the debt ceiling before the recess and that he does not expect a government shutdown. Furthermore, Mnuchin added that productive discussions were held with congressional leaders on the debt ceiling. (Newswires)

White House formally nominated Mark Esper for the US Defense Secretary position. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades lacklustre with global sentiment cautious heading into earnings season
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly subdued with the region indecisive following the modest finish on Wall St where all major indices notched fresh record highs before pulling back on cautiousness heading into earnings season. ASX 200 (+0.1%) is choppy as weakness across energy and financials offset the upside in mining names including Rio Tinto, as record high iron ore prices in China helped shares in the industry giant shrug off a decline in Q2 output and shipments. Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) underperforms on return from the extended weekend as it reacts to the recent downside in USD/JPY, while Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) are lacklustre as markets digest a slew of corporate earnings and guidance announcements but with downside also stemmed after the PBoC injected liquidity via open market operations following a 3-week hiatus.

In FX markets, the DXY remains firm and eyes a retest of the 97.00 level to the upside after the prior day’s gains, partially spurred by better than expected NY Fed Manufacturing data which showed the largest monthly increase in over 2 years. As such, its transatlantic counterparts are subdued with EUR/USD languishing near 1.1250 where there is a notable option expiry for today’s New York cut, while GBP/USD is stuck at the prior day’s lows and within close proximity to the 1.2500 level. In terms of the relevant stories, the Brexit negotiators’ meeting last week was said to be one of the most difficult with officials poising themselves for more hostile talks under the next UK government, and a recent note from Deutsche Bank suggested the probability of a ‘no-deal’ Brexit is at 45%. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is range-bound after having failed to sustain an early reclaim of the 108.00 handle and antipodeans are also relatively uneventful with only a muted reaction seen in AUD/USD from the RBA minutes which stated the board will adjust policy if needed to support growth which suggests the central bank will likely be data dependent, while NZD/USD gradually benefitted after Q2 CPI data printed inline with expectations.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are marginally higher following the recent upside in T-notes and amid the weakness in overnight risk sentiment, while the BoJ are also present in the market for 5yr-10yr JGBs.

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the July 2nd meeting where the central bank cut rates by 25bps to a fresh record low of 1.00% as expected, due at 0230BST/2030CDT/0930HKT
content:
At the meeting, the RBA cut the Cash Rate Target by 25bps for a 2nd consecutive meeting to 1.00% which was expected as ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had priced in as high as 89% probability for rates to be cut. The RBA stated that it lowered the Cash Rate to support employment growth and provide greater confidence on inflation.

The RBA’s statement noted that the economy can sustain a lower rate of unemployment and that employment growth remains strong, while it added that the outlook for the global economy remains reasonable but also commented downside risks from trade disputes are affecting investment globally. Furthermore, RBA Governor Lowe commented shortly after the meeting that 2 two cuts the Board delivered recently will make an important contribution to putting the economy on a better path and winding back spare capacity, although the Board is prepared to adjust interest rates again if needed to move closer to full employment and achieve the inflation target.

The initial reaction in AUD/USD to the rate announcement was to the downside although this was eventually pared as the statement didn’t provide much on forward guidance, while participants will be scrutinizing these minutes for any insight to support market expectations of another cut in November or whether it is a 'two and done' from the RBA.
